That Sophie realizes this alienation 20 years later is hardly a unique experience among young people today, which hurts far more than the film's fictional depiction. Bottom line: save your money, fix the culture.

reviews.review_title: One of the most realistic depictions of mental illness
reviews.content: Charlotte Wells' feature debut 'Aftersun' is an organic piece of filmmaking that is both heartwarming and heart-breaking. It isn't plot driven but rather more of a character study of two individuals, and moves between the past and present to give us a deeper insight into their lives and relationship. There is little dialogue and the pace is slow, but it subtly builds up to an ambiguous ending that resonates afterwards. Certainly not everyone will agree with this though, as the level of engagement with this film really depends on the viewers own experiences.The film is lead with two beautiful performances by Paul Mescal and Frankie Corio, who create a natural and heartfelt father-daughter relationship on screen. Mescal is at his best here and Corio is effortlessly compelling to say this is her first appearance. Their scenes are shot through a retro, grainy picture and the occasional Camcorder footage, which captures the films 90s setting and brings feelings of nostalgia. The concept of 'Aftersun' is such a simple one, but it is simultaneously complex and one of the most realistic depictions of mental illness.For more film reviews follow film.follower on Instagram.

reviews.review_title: An Oscar For The Worst Film Ever
reviews.content: I must've seen a different film....those high ratings for this absolute pap had me questioning whether my ice cream had one less ingredient than theirs!!This is about NOTHING!! I mean NOTHING and after suffering through the first hour of tortuous, disjointed, ridiculously distorted so called arty filmography I realised there wasn't going to be any story! Beware if you're an epileptic or suffer from migraine....the hideous persistent use of strobe lighting could cause a major medical episode.If only I had chosen to do the ironing instead of losing almost 2 hours of my life watching this rubbish.

reviews.review_title: Quite the directorial debut from Charlotte Wells
reviews.content: That last shot, it kills me man.This is a beautiful movie, one of the best-shot of the year, and it's anchored by two great performances with perfect father-daughter chemistry. These aspects make up for the lack of momentum and/or story beats in the movie, though I do understand that the story this movie is telling doesn't necessarily require a lot of momentum.The long takes and stretches of silence make the movie feel really comfortable and lived-in, and it's jarring how this movie is disguised as feel-good while really telling a harrowing story behind the sun-soaked relaxing. I love the fact that we don't ever really know what Calum's deal is, because it puts us as the audience in the exact same place as Sophie: We spend time with this seemingly really sweet man... and then he's gone, and we're left wondering what went wrong.The Under Pressure scene is so good but so tough.

Aftersun is...different experience. One of those movies that is not as interesting as the emotion it invokes in you. It can be discussed for hours and hours. I see people write longer reviews than the script. I get it. I liked it. Some scenes really got to me. Especially the ending. But at the end of the day, i don't really know how many people, me included, would ever rewatch this? Not because it's one of those movies that is so sad and draining that you can't stand to see it again, but more because the experience itself is not engaging enough to fully justify the way it makes you feel after the credits roll. In this case, parallel reflection with our own lives is what gets us to tears more than drama on the screen. But hey, that is a fine accomplishment on its own as well.Anyways, 2 leads are good. I really liked Charlotte Wells' direction for the most part and all of her subtle touches across the movie. I would definitely like to see what she does next.It's a bit too A24-ish for my taste, but i appreciate it nonetheless.

What a boring movie. And why Paul Mescal got a nomination to Oscar ?! He plays exactly like in Normal People. Maybe people will enjoy it if they didn't see other work of his.I really don't understand all the positive high ratings for this movie. Sooo slow. Literally nothing happened the whole movie. Just kept waiting for anything to happen. A few nice photography but nothing else.If you're looking for entertainment this is not where you are going to get it. The movie is an hour and 42 minutes Don't waste your time.An ordinary, slow, boring film in which nothing happens. This movie is not only boring, pointless and confusing, but it has zero acting, screenplay and dialogue are pathetic.

reviews.review_title: Great directorial debut, but overall pointless
reviews.content: Let's start with the pros. The performances are pretty solid, there's good cinematography, and overall the movie looks and sounds good.Where it falls apart is in my opinion pacing and plot. The movie is marketed as a daugther recollecting this vacation, supposedly to reflect on her father figure. Now mind you, I watched it without looking anything up except for the general reception, so I went in with a complete blank slate.Soon enough I thought this was going to be one of "those" movies. That is: full of seemingly pointless scenes that sometimes drag too long for no good reason. And I was more or less right, as by the end of it I kinda wonder what the director wanted to say about these characters. I appreciate not spoon-feeding the audience, but by the end of the movie we barely know anything about the father, other than that he's in some financial distress (but that begs the question of how he afforded what doesn't look like a cheap vacation oversea when he cares about losing a diving mask), and that he's depressed on some level. Other than some mood swings and quirky moments we don't really "reflect" on his personality that much.Plus, adult Sophie could be cut from the movie and absolutely nothing would change. We get 10 seconds of time skip about one hour in to find out she's lesbian and has a daughter. Neither of those have any relation to anything in the movie. Then there's another timeskip at the very end, and that doesn't add anything either.Overall a very anemic experience.

Aftersun is a beautiful work of art with stunning performances and courageous direction.It is a reflection of memory - the memory of a father. He is a tormented person suffering from crippling depression. He attempts to not allow to his pain to ruin his limited time with his beloved preteen daughter.Paul Mescal gives a brilliant performance. In my opinion it is the finest performance by an actor I have seen this year. He has the gift of connecting with his audience on a spiritual level. You can sense his characters inner life and suffering just by gazing into his eyes. I was mesmerized by his performance.This is not a conventional film. It demands concentration and patience. It is, however, a brilliant journey well worth your time.

Aftersun is very very slow, but builds a very effective melancholy.It is pretty, well shot, well acted, and ultimately a portrait of the kind of emotion that is difficult to put into words. She makes this feel very easy to relate to and clear, or at least as clear as such a naturally opaque emotion can be.While I don't think it has particularly anything interesting to offer that other, similar artistic works haven't already shown, it is still a movie worth watching, and as good art does it caused me to consider my own emotions and how they relate to the special moments I have with my own family.

This film just checks all the boxes. First when reading the synopsis, I wasn't really intrigued and it's not the most interesting film of the year. But the way it's told, the cinematography, the performances, the sound track...it just all comes together brilliantly in the most subtle possible way. Not everything is handed to the audience and that's okay, because like the protagonist, not everything is explained to her. There's no real plot or hidden messages, at least I don't think, just get lost in the relationship with the father and daughter and think about your own memories with your parents. Never have I seen a film say so much without saying much at all.

On a summer evening with the wind blowing, people gather in twos and threes on the open-air stage. Sophie asks Calum, "You excited for tomorrow?"
This is the moment when "Aftersun" reveals its intentions. In such a restrained narrative, a question like this is a flaw. At this point, time is no longer a lingering old image, it becomes a specific, private experience with a paragraph - the experience of father and daughter cannot be aligned regarding tomorrow.The biggest difference between adults and children is tomorrow. Tomorrow for children is pocket change, as if there is always another token that can start a new game by being invested. A lot of tomorrow is like the all-inclusive wristband at a resort hotel, which Sophie inherited from a mature older sister. She was proud of herself that night, kissing the little boy by the pool is a billionaire's demand for more freedom; tomorrow for adults is a part of the future, and the future is often dark, constituting Calum's moments of losing focus, crying, and going to the deep sea."You excited for tomorrow?" Calum nods slightly. A standard adult response. Years later, Sophie will also remember her father in an adult-style ambiguity, that summer, the experiences during the trip, and everything becomes unimportant, only emotions are real. Emotions anchor people to time.The lost time cannot fill a heart today. We still don't know the father's life (why did he cry loudly in the middle of the night? Why did he separate from his wife? Why did he have a 10-year-old daughter at the age of 30?), because life is a narrative concept. " "aftersun"" does not pursue the accuracy and completeness of narrative, it only shows time. The father is the person in time, he has no origin or destination, on that time slice, the 30-year-old father is eternal. Today's Sophie is not the Sophie by the pool, time does not change anything, everything in the past is eternal. This is more thorough than Proust, who once wrote:
"It seems that it is only through some eternal changes that we feel the great differences between the samples taken at intervals, and feel that we are the same as them and also follow this rule. They are still themselves, but are no longer like them".At the end, the father turns off the DV, leaves, opens the door, and it's the dark dance floor with chaotic lights. What is the constantly flashing dark dance floor in " "Aftersun"? I think it's like a nightmare, an unhappy thing, hidden in the gap of time. To return to that holiday, or another better holiday, you must follow time, pass through the dark dance floor, and pass through these shadows. How heavy and simple it is.

reviews.review_title: Beat if you know nothing about it beforehand.
reviews.content: I had read nothing about the film, only that it's an Oscar contender so, as this is the year I'm trying to watch Oscar nominated films (which can so often be so darned dull) I watched it. I admit I was waiting for something to happen for a bit but did realise the type of film this was going to be, so slowed down and just watched it. It's an odd film, not much happens but it really worms its way under your skin. You really are effectively watching someone's holiday. It's normal, like the everyday holiday that we've all been on. And that's why it works for me. I found the film and the ending very charming and I was moved by it.My advice/ DON'T READ ANYTHING ABOUT IT. Because when you do, my Lord it makes the film much less enjoyable.When watched as I did, it's a lovely little film based on normal life and families and not always knowing what's going on with people, behind the smiles, everyone trying to make moments special, families, regret, love and loss. When you read about what the film is intended to be, it veers quickly into so damn pretentious and rather obnoxious. It also falls short as it relies on the viewer to make a number of assumptions that just aren't shown, which is irritating. I'm going to try and forget I read any of that stuff and just remember the film for what I thought it was and will rate it accordingly.

reviews.review_title: The more you watch, the more you understand
reviews.content: This movie leaves me hanging and wanting more at the end, and at the same time triggering to dive deeper to the void I've been escaping my whole life; on fatherhood. A very good movie to watch. This just feels so real, so raw.I'd love to watch this again some time in the future - this will definitely give different meaning as we grow older. You can see yourself becoming the kid, and one day in the parent's position.Talks so much about how hard it is to deal with mental health that might not be visible on the outside but hurts a lot in the inside. After the last scene I can't hear Under Pressure the same again. Must watch.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful film making. Cried my eyes out!
reviews.content: This movie will make you feel uneasy throughout. Like you know somethings wrong and something bad is going to happen but you just can't quite put your finger on it.The director very skilfully edges the audience right up until the credits. It's only then that all the subtle clues fall into place and you can make your mind up about what happened because it doesn't freely give you the answer.A film that gives you a true sense of feeling those memories and hanging onto them with loved ones.I've never watched a film that made me feel and live the emotions as if I was in the story before. Brilliant. Absolutely heartbreakingly brilliant.This director is amazing as are the cast. Bring tissues.

This film for me, is one of the best and most transformative examples of modern slow cinema, it molds the long takes, the quiet performances and all the tools Charlotte Wells has at her disposal to create a meaningful experience outside of the usual narrative structure.It uses the quiet ambience and the subtle aesthetics of the films environment and it's characters to tell a deeply tragic and intimate story of depression and the relationship you have with your parents.The cinematography is absolutely gorgeous, which both plants us in the POV of Sophie at points, and at other points, envelopes us in this ethereal, dreamlike beauty of a small spring break holiday. Paul Mescal gives the performance of the year no doubt, where he's able to express balance of being a compassionate and reckless dad and having this deeply painful depressive state bubbling up a lot of the time, in a really subtle and nuanced way.The electronic ambient score by Oliver Coates really adds to this ethereal ambience I've mentioned before with its use of synths in this minimal soundscape, which all culminates in the 'Under Pressure' finale, something that feels transcendental in all its elements.

Watching Aftersun feeled like watching somebody's homevideoes. I feeled like I was invading a families private space. The movie is shot in such a beautiful way. There is a lot of thoughts behind every scene in the movie. As the viewer you do not know where the movie will take you to until the last scene. The ending scene bought me to tears, such a touching moment where you know nothing about what happens next. The ending scene is very open and will leave you in tears because we will never know what happens after.The movie is not for everyone. If you like watching a movie for the aesthetic and cinematography this movie is for you.

This is hella overrated. The only thing in the movie is a daughter and dad going on a vacation. Nothing tragic or tense happens. If I recorded myself sleeping, that'd be a greater movie than this. They sing karaoke, go scuba-diving and visit a carpet seller etc. These are activities you can also do in your ordinary life. People literally watch movies to see extraordinary things. At least they should've put a plot twist or something. At one point, I even hoped one of the characters to crush under the car so it would at least be dramatic. The next time I go on a vacation with my family, I'll record it. Maybe I win an Oscar prize for it. Not recommending.

As a voting member of Film Independent, I am sent links to all the films. I am so disappointed in After Sun. Nothing happened. It was slow as molasses and I am unsure as to how or why it was made. I was looking forward to this film but I was confused as to if the child was a boy or girl. In that they shared a bed with their father for two weeks. The acting was disappointing. At one point the father is "crying" but they don't show his face and he sounds like he is laughing. There were no other emotions demonstrated on the screen. I have never seen a film whereby it felt like they were reading a book out loud and David of any emotion. Very disappointed.

Very few films leave you haunted. This movie hasn't left me. The narrative appears linear with very little plot until a couple of poignant moments rip your heart out of your chest. For a debut this incredibly confident film making. It feels very personal. The protagonists are spot on. There are a lot of unanswered questions but that is credit to the direction and writing in how it makes you be involved. For me this is a brilliant accomplishment that will no doubt be ignored in favour of larger budgets and bigger names. Talent this raw should not be ignored in my opinion but would probably be spoilt given unlimited resources.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful, a perfect theme but whimsical
reviews.content: Aftersun was such a beautiful movie that looked at emotion and how it could show it in such a unique way. In some of the scenes it felt so real and observant on every day life that you start to doubt what were your own experiences as a child and adult and not a collective experience.I so wanted to adore this movie with it's subtle dialogue, sparse soundtrack and great themes.But I just couldn't.What aftersun does well, it does in almost the best way I've seen. It feels like it's captured the emotions of being a teen on a family holiday so perfectly it shocked me. The twinges of jealousy of other lives, romanticising some of the older kids, the colours even!But unfortunately the overriding feeling for me was it needed more story. Something needed to take me from scene to scene and feel like I was watching a movie. By half way through it felt like I was sitting in an art museum watching one of the art video installations. Lovely film work, an emotional theme, but not enough to grab you for a feature length film.A 6/10 for me, but any movie that pushes to try something new grabs an extra 2 stars from me to see more movies like it!

This is a masterpiece. The dancing scene will be studied for decades and will go down as one of the great scenes in film history. Truly heartbreaking but perspective changing.What blew my breath away was how the underlying story crept up so silently but how elegantly the clues had been weaved in in hindsight. A slowly intensifying sense of dread stirs throughout without any specific source to pinpoint, though the last 15 mins were the ultimate payoff."Love dares you to care for the people on the edge of the night" - I will never listen to "Under pressure" the same way. A stunning feature debut from Charlotte Wells, probably the best I've ever seen. Also major shoutout to Frankie Corio, sensational debut for her, the chemistry between her and Paul Mescal (who is unsurprisingly brilliant as always) was so natural and heartfelt.Thank you for creating this art.

This film impacted me in such a way that I felt compelled to create an IMDb account just so I could review it. For those who struggle with slow-burners, this film may not be for you but for anyone else, I struggle to see how one could fail to fall in love with it.Aftersun is a celebration of fatherhood, a warm embrace to the millions of men who battle their demons daily and a quiet, subtle entry into the cinema H. O. F.Paul Mescal puts on a stellar performance. His ability to convey emotion is second to none. After his breakthrough with Normal People, I thought he may have peaked early but no, Mescal manages to match his previous performances.Frankie Corio does a superb job and I'll be expecting big things from her in the future.For anyone who hasn't yet witnessed this masterpiece, make sure to give it your undivided attention. The subtle hints throughout the film will help you paint the story for yourself and help you digest what is for me, one of the most impactful films from this century.

It is not a film, is a therapy session. It doesn't develop the character (shopie) as an adult and the traumas or consequences of child and father relationship. You may think that is what lacking in the movie after you see it, but actually is so subtle that makes you think about yourself and the development process of character is on you, yes you, the final character delvelopment is yourself, spectator. On the end you will start to think about your own relationship with your father during childhood and how it was by the time, when you just couldn't see completely how things really were, but feel it just in part. The subtle plot doesn't make you miss it when directing takes the lead on this film, it could be a mute movie and you'd still feel it just by the directing work. And always remember that we are still just the same, just like our parents.

With high expectations gleaned from its IMDb rating, I settled in to watch this film. However, within the initial half hour, I found myself underwhelmed and struggling to remain engaged. Despite the lavish praise it had received, I couldn't help but question the validity of such adoration. After all, todays user critics can often be influenced by a certain political bias.The lack of compelling storytelling and foreseen plot twists only exacerbated my disappointment. The performances, particularly the lead's attempts to imitate the Joker through a series of slow-motion dance sequences, failed to impress and left me puzzled as to how this actor received an Oscar nomination while Robert De Niro's stunning performance in "The Irishman" went unnoticed.While the cinematography did showcase some creative flair, the editing left much to be desired.This film serves as a prime example of today's cinematic biases and the danger of getting caught up in the hype.

reviews.review_title: A thoughtful exploration of a troubled family
reviews.content: This is the best film I have seen in a long time.It reels you in with an appropriately slow development of the characters, beautifully played by Paul Mescal and Frankie Corio, as they do their best to connect and enjoy a vacation in Turkey. You see the relationship develop and change as Frankie's character is entering and dealing with puberty. This is done with sensitivity and crafty cinematography by director, Charlotte Wells. Just as you're comfortable with this and seeing hints of the turmoil that the father is dealing with, the movie turns around and punches you in the gut with raw emotion and revelation.If you don't have a developed emotional intelligence this might not be the film for you, if you do, keep the tissue box nearby. This movie will move you!

This is clearly very much a minority opinion, but this reviewer is at a complete loss to understand the rave notices this film has received.Aftersun is little more than a vehicle for Paul Mescal to appear with very few clothes on, presumably keeping his female fans from Normal People reasonably happy.Lacking drama, tension, pacing, plot, anything of any interest at all. A low budget film set in the 1990s that looks as if it is a low budget film made in the 1990s, except it lacks the freshness of the sort of films it apes.The characters and performances are largely one-dimensional and clichéd. Avoid.

This film is like a feeling as opposed to a complete story. There is very little exposition but as the movie progresses you learn just enough to feel what the characters are going through, which also leaves space for the audience to fill in the blanks. What I took away most from this movie was that the acting rang true. While we mostly watch movies for escapism or pure entertainment, it's refreshing to see a film that's just a snapshot of a stranger's life, but one that we can feel empathy for and in some ways relate to. Life is hard, but we do the best we can. Sometimes nice things will happen along the way. And it's the good memories we create for each other that makes the world, both real and fictional, a better place.

reviews.review_title: At first you don't understand why you're watching it, and then you don't turn it off on the credits
reviews.content: The first 20-30 minutes you just watch the rest of the father and daughter and do not understand at all why you need someone's family video, which may be of interest only to members of their family.But then you start to notice the details that indicate the direction of their mood. And then it started. You get more and more worried about every action in the scene, every look.By the 70th minute, Calum is increasingly immersed in darkness. His clothes get darker and he gets darker in the frame. And then the moment comes when he completely goes into the black void. On a dark dark night, in black black clothes, he ran into the black sea and disappeared... Suicide? Everything was leading up to this. No need! Come back!At this time, his 11-year-old daughter Sophie spends time with older acquaintances who are filled with alcohol. And then she was alone at night. Something is definitely going to happen now. Only not this!A hotel worker opens the door to Sophie's room, and there is Calum sleeping on the bed. Fuh! Both of you are fine. If not for his daughter, Calum would definitely not have returned. His love for her is stronger than himself.But! When they got home and parted at the end, he definitely killed himself. I am sure about that. It's shown. You can see it, but you refuse to believe it. That's what you think about all the time that the end credits are running.

The acting is absolutely superb and the overall feel is realistic. But it is a very slow-paced artsy film that does not wish to make itself understood and prouds itself in that.It does convey great unease and provoke anxiety without you understanding why. It leaves you with a lot of questions and the reoccurring strobe scenes were absolutely obnoxious. It's certainly very "different" and unique in it's way to provoke emotion (for me mostly frustration).Overall its a good movie, but I can barley recommend anyone to watch it. I had a bit of the same feeling when watching the Triangle of Sadness that also has a lot of great acting and more, but is so overly slow-paced, artsy and would have been better as a shorter cut.

Simple, detailed, and intimate. Aftersun does a perfect job as a piece of art that portrays the fragile relationship of a kid and her father. On one side there is a young, confused and bruised man. And on the other, there is a little girl that wants to have a good vacation, but, apart from that, a good relationship with her father. This movie tells the public that every parent out there is living their first life, as well as their kids. It's acceptable to not be there and well all the time, but for the male adult Callum is a requirement for him to be partially there, not with his mind, but at least with his body. The young Sophie is still getting to know who she is and what might have caused their relationship to be seeming strange sometimes.The end of the movie shared a peak on the adult Sophie revisiting their summer vacation, and relieving her old paternal memories. But at the same time, Sophie's expression gives the feeling that she is trying to understand something, and, in my point of view, she is getting to realize that her father wasn't all there because other things rather than having no money and no girlfriend were affecting him, like his mental health, something that made her young self be, sometimes, upset on how her dad wasn't happy and excited all the time, like she was.

The most fragmented and pure memories of director Charlotte Wells are here exposed as pieces of a whole.Though perhaps not even the director, much less the viewer, will be able to put together this puzzle, the beauty of which lies in the fact that it is incomplete.Simply the vision of a daughter about her father, in a simple summer holiday in Turkey, permeating moments in swimming pools and hotel rooms, to paradisiacal landscapes and historical sights, but all supporting actors, in the protagonism of the connection of both.The parental bond and the capacity of an adult, to protect the innocence of a child, hiding his problems, insecurities and fears, preserving the best moments of a young girl, from what was filmed by their camera, to the camera of the film itself, in a dichotomy of the digital and the tangible, of the past and the present, with cinema being the bridge for this.Showing to be happy, even when not, as an act of supreme love, the continuation of the other, the division of life, the union of the two in a family unit.

Scottish cinema is clearly alive and kicking to produce this masterpiece.Absolutely brilliant film, beautifully shot, with an amazing soundtrack, well rounded characters and a really nice story. It really does have it all.Feels like the work of an established director and cast so to pull this off with limited experience is even more remarkable, the film flies by and gives way to your own ponderings of childhood and family holidays. The sunny scapes are a perfect antidote to winter weather.You certainly won't be disappointed in catching this on the big screen where you can emerse yourself into the story.

reviews.review_title: Touching and deep, funny and heartwarming at times, but definitely heartbreaking.
reviews.content: Endless vacation, 90's hotels with thousands of crappy activities that your father refuses to attend, lots of new pool friends, the hotel has become your new mini-city full of corners to explore. Joining in with the grow-ups and not fitting in, although you don't like playing anymore with the little ones and feeling lost among so many new and unknown pre-adolescent sensations. Back in your thirties, feeling even more lost. Desperate and failed attempt to take refuge in that place where everything was safe, although your nobel intelligence already sensed that it would not last forever. Best movie of the year.

reviews.review_title: Not a masterpiece, not a bad movie
reviews.content:
Tbh, this feels like a RAW movie, more like on the side of indie projects compared to mainstream movies.I think the movie gives you a good experience of what is to have a father's love, but it fails to deliver a conclusion imo. I have two theories what could happened at the end, one is the father going to buy some cigarettes and vanish from existence, or a more powerful theory based on what I saw on the movie, is a suicidal father.Yeet

It's literally a film about a dad and his daughter on holiday. Just a bog standard holiday where nothing special happens. That is 99% of the film. 1% of the film you see that the dad is sad and struggling with life, and you need to untangle the ending and what the point of the film was. And because you had to unravel the subtleties of the film people are calling it a masterpiece.. which makes absolutely no sense. If you want to see a film that's gripping or entertaining, watch something else. This felt like watching paint dry and had me scratching my head throughout wondering when something would happen and what the point of the film was.

This is an astounding cinematic experience. I found each scene to be mesmerising and it felt as if I was living the moments of Calum and Sophie. I found it hard to breath sometimes terrified that something bad was going to happen to one of them. When the movie was about to end I fooled myself into thinking they made it home safely which they probably did. Once it sunk in that Calum was gone I felt my heart break into a million pieces. I will watch it again for sure because I feel an emotional attachment and I want to learn more about what transpired on that sunny Turkish holiday. No other film has affected me in such a way but I suspect the rawness was heightened by a recent trip home to see my Dad and finding photos from his youth and early days of being a new parent in the 60's that he had not seen for decades. Memories are so powerful.

The dialogue is just mere punctuation in this visual and sonic treat that slowly unfurls, and will leave an aching feeling in the pit of your stomach for days after watching it. The acting, direction, colour and sound design are all incredible, and the father-daughter relationship depicted by Paul Mescal and Frankie Corio is so believable and tender. The whole thing feels like authentic, heartbreaking, memory. It's hard to believe this is a debut feature film from the director as everything is delivered with such confidence and deftness. So coherent, so good, I can't recommend it highly enough.

What a wonderful movie. It is tender, loving and reflective of a healthy and wholesome relationship between a father and his. The movie focuses on the two main characters bringing everything else into the background. There is beauty throughout the movie. The acting is so natural that it made me think several times that this was an unrehearsed home movie. In many ways it was just that and therefore the incredible charm.This movie was total visual poetry. In musical terms there were just the right amount of notes, silent rests and surprising melodic changes.Cuddle up with your loved one, have a glass of wine or favorite spirit and enjoy.

reviews.review_title: We don't realize how good our memories were until we miss them...

ThisIt’s one thing for a movie to be subtle and nuanced, but it’s something else entirely to be enigmatic and cryptic. And, regrettably, the debut feature from writer-director Charlotte Wells delivers more of the latter than the former. This melancholic character study tells the story of a woman (Celia Rowlson-Hall) who looks back 20 years to a vacation that her perky 11-year-old self (Frankie Corio) took with her young and loving but quietly troubled father (Paul Mescal). In doing so, it explores the subjects of memory, parent-child relationships, mental and emotional well-being, and the various senses of loss we all experience over time, topics that the protagonist’s youthful counterpart may not have fully understood at the time but that her adult self now does. I wish I could say the same for myself, though; I often felt that I was being tasked to construct a narrative for the picture myself, based, essentially, on merely what was being shown to me, material that frequently comes across as underdeveloped and open to an array of interpretation in terms of both story line and character development. To put it simply, I didn’t feel I was given enough substance to work with to accomplish that task, and it often left me feeling wanting, abandoned by the filmmaker, and, ultimately, uninterested. And, to complicate matters further, the film’s poor sound quality regularly obscures the characters’ dialogue behind their thick Scottish accents, and its often-dark, overly muddled cinematography made some images difficult to decipher at times. What’s more, this offering’s camera work – aimed at simulating glorified home movies, a fitting approach for telling this story – is packed with innocuous material. Indeed, who really cares about sitting through endless footage of the characters engaging in mundane activities like playing video games, eating ice cream and attempting to sing karaoke? The “looking back in fondness” factor in these supposedly touching segments is a little too inane to engender truly heart-tugging feelings, constituting cinematic padding more than anything integral or meaningful to the overall story. Considering all of the advance glowing reactions I had read about this release, I was really looking forward to it going in. Unfortunately, though, I came away from it almost as sad and disappointed as the protagonist herself.

The sense of melancholy I felt while watching the film left me with the understanding that for Sophie, 20 years of loss seems a lifetime, while her memories feel like only yesterday.
